div.ab: Spanish Romances. most ancient are of 13 century – the last of the 15thWG's error. The original French says 'la fin du seizième siècle', the end of the 16th century..
some really translated from Arabic. written in reigns of Aben Hassan. Muley Abdallah & Boabdil. Romances of Rodriguez later.
But those of Rodrigo the oldest.
Bernardo del Carpio son of Sancho Diaz Ct Count of Saldaña & a Dauri.e. a Daughter, WG's error. The original French says 'une soeur', a sister. of Alphonso the chaste.
Fernan Gonzales Ct of Castille.
Adarga a round shield. Azagaya a javelin
El Marabeth. Morabeth a Tribe of Zahara.
Alcala Castle or Citadel.
Mudexares = tributaries?i.e. mudéjares. From the Arabic for subjugated, tamed or domesticated; and, by extension in Spanish, those Muslims who remained in Iberia after the Reconquista.
Alcayceria the bazar.

“Cries resound in the Towers of the Alhambra & through the City of Granada in all parts. For without reason the King has beheaded in one day 36 abencerrages nobles of great valour. Accused by the Zegries & Gomeles of treason. All the Dames weep all that are in Granada. From the windows & open galleries are shewn mourning draperies..”WG's translation from the Bibliothèque universelle's French, p. 258: ‘Dans les tours de l’Alhambra de grands cris retentissent; dans la cité de Grenade des gémissemens résonnent de toutes parts; ‘Car sans aucun motif, le roi a fait décapiter en un seul jour trente six Abencerrages, nobles de grand bravoure ... que les Zégris et les Goméles accusoient de trahison … ‘Toutes les dames les pleuroient, toutes celles que renferme Grenade; des fenêtres et des façades des maisons tombent des draperies de deuil.’
Alhama taken by Don Rodrigo Ponce de Leon in 1483.
Rioverde under Rondai.e. the Río Verde river
Sierra bermeja between Malaga & Gibraltar.
Fernando Perez de PulgarHernán Pérez del Pulgar (1451-1531) wrote avemaria on mosque door.
div.note: From ‘Sur les romances espagnols’, Bibliothèque universelle des sciences, belles-lettres, et arts, vol. 46 (1831), pp. 225-62, at pp. 227-8, 231, 233, 248, 251, 258, 260-1.
div.ab: De Rasis. Hist History from Arabic translated into Spanish ergo true historyWG's addition. tum notabilia quaedam inde excerpta & diligenter examinata.From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. xxiii. By Rasis. History from Arabic translated into Spanish therefore true history. Then some noteworthy things extracted from it and carefully examined.

Pedro de Lara aothe year (anno) 1611 near Salè took 2 ships of Zidan Kg of Morocco. took 3000 MSSManuscripts. King offered 70 000 Ducats for ransom. Kg of Spain answered he would have the release of all the XtianChristian Slaves. The Kg Zeidan would have given them but having war with un Morabito y con su sobrino Muley Xequea Marabout Muslim holy man or hermit and his brother, Sheikh Muley could not, so the books went to the Escurial. Vida y hechos del Rey D. Phelipe III. by Gonzales DavilaCasiri cites a 17th-century manuscript history of the life and deeds of King Don Philip III by [Gil] González Dávila, kept in the Royal Library at Madrid.. Many burnt June 7 1671.WG's translation of Spanish and Latin from Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. iv-v. Casiri gives most of this text in Spanish in a footnote, but additional comments from the main text are in Latin. Joseph [Giuseppe] Baretti, A Journey from London to Genoa, through England, Portugal, Spain, and France, 3rd edn, 4 vols (London, 1770), vol. 3, pp. 82-4 gives the Spanish with an English translation, citing Casiri. WG was drawing directly on Casiri, though: not only does he leave untranslated Spanish, but he also dates the Escorial fire precisely, as only Casiri does, and avoids Baretti's error of 1761.
Ualadata daughter of Kg Mohamad Almostakphi Billa Kg of Spain Poesies in quantity.

De Urbe Ramla or RamaOn the City of Ramla by Ebn AlkalifeThis is not in Casiri. It is possible WG has misunderstood Casiri's attributions and written 'Ebn Alkalife' in error because Casiri attributes an earlier work to Ebn Alkhathib., who gives history also of Samarcand &c. also of the Bibliotheca of Porphyrius.Library of Porphyry [of Tyre]
Dioscorides. Hippocrates. Galen. Plato. Euclid. Ptolemy. Zoroaster. of the city Tadmir.
On Cannon & Nitrati pulveris potassium nitrate powder [i.e. gunpowder]& the ancient use of paper by the Arabs. Nubian Geographer.
De Nominis Andalusia etymo Etymology of the name Andalusia–
Many of these were in library – Royal at Granada but taken at the fall to Morocco.

note.bibl: From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, pp. xix-xxiii.
